title: How Sunday newspapers reacted to Boris Johnson's Brexit defeat
text:
Newspapers have slammed MPs who dealth the prime minister a humiliating blow in Parliament on Saturday by demanding he request a Brexit delay.

After suffering the embarrassing defeat in the Commons over his Brexit plans, Mr Johnson got a senior diplomat to send Brussels an unsigned photocopy of the call by MPs to delay withdrawal from the bloc, with a cover note stressing his detachment from the move.

He then sent his own personal note to European Council president Donald Tusk saying a Brexit extension would be ‘deeply corrosive’.

Reaction to the Super Saturday sitting was strong across the Sunday papers, with a headline dubbing Parliament ‘The House of Fools’.

The Mail on Sunday wrote: ‘Today Britain could have begun to heal after the end of our Brexit purgatory. Instead, posturing MPs subjected us to yet more agonising delay.’

The Sunday Express features a front page picture of a glum looking Boris Johnson and a headline asking ‘Why won’t they let us leave?’

Advertisement

Advertisement

But The Observer applauded the MPs who caused another delay in the Brexit process saying Boris Johnson ‘is a prime minister without a mandate’.

MP’s who supported the Letwin amendment were labelled the ‘Brexit wreckers’ by The Times (Picture: The Sunday Times)

The Observer argued MPs were given very little time to study the terms of the most important decision the country has faced in decades (Picture: The Observer)

‘He has never faced an election and has lost every vote he has put to the House of Commons,’ the paper said in its editorial.

It said MPs were given very little time to study the terms of the most important decision the country has faced in decades.

It said: ‘(Mr Johnson) miscalculated badly.

‘Parliament reasserted its sovereignty, voting to withhold approval of his EU deal until MPs have a chance to scrutinise the relevant legislation, effectively forcing him by law to request an extension from the EU.’

The Sunday Mirror’s front page deatures a one word headline: ‘Humiliated.’

It goes on to say that Mr Johnson has been ‘forced to beg’ the EU for another Brexit delay.

But The Sunday Telegraph’s editorial reads: ‘All is not lost if Tories get behind the PM.’

It adds: ‘This dithering and disgraced Parliament made a complete fool of itself yesterday.

‘Instead of voting in sensible order on the new Brexit deal – for which the Government seemed so tantalisingly close to a majority – it passed Sir Oliver Letwin’s preposterous amendment, kicking Brexit into the long grass yet again.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

The paper ended its editorial with what it calls a ‘recipe to restore trust in British politics’, saying: ‘We must leave the EU as soon as possible and we need a new generation of MPs who remember exactly who put them there.’

While the Express described Mr Johnson as ‘defiant’ (Picture: Sunday Express)

While the Mail on Sunday branded MP’s the ‘House of Fools’ (Picture: The Mail)

This morning, shadow chancellor John McDonnell has insisted Mr Johnson may be in contempt of Parliament over his decision to distance himself from a Brexit extension.

Mr McDonnell hit out at the way the prime minister sent the legally required request to the EU for a Brexit delay – which he refused to sign.

The Labour MP accused Mr Johnson of ‘behaving a bit like a spoilt brat’ after he stressed to Brussels he was only sending the communication at Parliament’s bidding.

Speaking on Sky News’s Sophy Ridge on Sunday, Mr McDonnell said: ‘He may well be in contempt of Parliament or the courts themselves because he’s clearly trying to undermine the first letter and not signing the letter.

‘Parliament made a decision, he should abide by it and this idea that you send another letter contradicting the first, I think it flies in the face of what both Parliament and the courts have decided.’

The PM rang European leaders, including Mr Tusk, on Saturday night declaring that the letter ‘is Parliament’s letter, not my letter’.

The Benn Act set a deadline of 11pm on Saturday for the Prime Minister to get a deal if the UK is to leave on October 31, otherwise he is supposed to seek an extension.

Advertisement

Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg said the Government was planning to give MPs a fresh chance to have a ‘meaningful vote’ on the deal hammered out by Mr Johnson with Brussels on Monday.

Speaker John Bercow said he would rule on Monday whether it was in order for the Government to hold the vote, after not pressing ahead with it on Saturday following its defeat on the Letwin amendment.
